definitions: concerning or based on the relationships between people, things, or concepts
relating to database structures where data is organized in tables with defined relationships
examples: The therapy focused on relational dynamics between family members
Their relational difficulties stemmed from poor communication habits
This relational database stores customer information across multiple linked tables
The relational model provides better data integrity than flat files

definitions: considered in relation or proportion to something else rather than absolutely
a person connected by blood or marriage to another person
examples: The relative importance of each factor varies by situation
Their relative positions in the race changed constantly
Several relatives attended the wedding from both families
My distant relative lives in another country altogether

definitions: free from tension and anxiety with muscles at rest and mind calm
having an informal atmosphere or approach without strict rules or formality
examples: She felt completely relaxed after the massage therapy session
His relaxed posture showed he was comfortable here
The restaurant has a relaxed dress code for diners
Their relaxed approach to deadlines created a pleasant atmosphere

definitions: making someone feel calm and comfortable without stress or tension
examples: The spa offered relaxing massages and aromatherapy treatments
Listening to relaxing music helps me fall asleep
We spent a relaxing weekend at the beach resort
The garden provides a relaxing environment for reading

definitions: in the process of setting free or letting go of something held
in the act of making something available to the public or market
examples: The releasing mechanism slowly opened the parachute automatically
The dam was releasing water to prevent overflow
The company is releasing new products next quarter
They're releasing the report to the media today

definitions: continuing without becoming weaker or less severe in determination or intensity
harsh and inflexible showing no sign of mercy or compassion
examples: The relentless rain continued for three days straight
Her relentless pursuit of excellence inspired the team
The prosecutor's relentless questioning broke down his defense
The relentless criticism eventually destroyed his confidence completely

definitions: closely connected or appropriate to the matter being considered or discussed
examples: Please provide only relevant information for this investigation
Her experience is highly relevant to this position
The most relevant studies were published last year
These documents contain relevant evidence for the case

definitions: consistently good in quality or performance and able to be trusted
examples: She's the most reliable employee in our department
This car has proven reliable over many years
We need reliable sources for our research paper
The weather forecast is generally reliable for tomorrow

definitions: needing or depending on someone or something for support or survival
examples: The economy is heavily reliant on tourism revenue
Children are reliant on their parents for care
We're too reliant on imported oil for energy
The patient is still reliant on life support

definitions: feeling happy and relaxed because something difficult or unpleasant has stopped
examples: She felt relieved when the test results came back negative
Parents were relieved to see their children safe
He looked visibly relieved after hearing the good news
I'm so relieved that everything worked out well

definitions: having been voluntarily given up or surrendered, especially with reluctance
examples: The relinquished territory was returned to its original owners
His relinquished position was filled within days
The relinquished control over the company proved costly
Their relinquished rights could not be easily restored

definitions: having been moved to a new place or position, especially permanently
examples: The relocated families adjusted to their new neighborhood
Our relocated office is closer to downtown
The relocated factory provides jobs for local workers
Several relocated employees received housing assistance this year

definitions: unwilling and hesitant to do something because of doubt or lack of enthusiasm
examples: She was reluctant to share personal information with strangers
The reluctant witness finally agreed to testify
He gave a reluctant smile when asked about it
The board showed reluctant approval of the proposal

definitions: continuing to exist or be left after other parts have been removed or used
examples: The remaining tickets sold out within minutes
We spent our remaining time exploring the city
Only three remaining contestants advanced to the finals
The remaining balance is due next month

definitions: worthy of attention because of being unusual, extraordinary, or striking in quality
examples: She made remarkable progress in just six months
The view from the mountain was truly remarkable
His remarkable memory impressed everyone at the meeting
They achieved remarkable results despite limited resources available

definitions: intended to correct or improve deficient skills or knowledge in students
intended to cure or heal a disease or medical condition
examples: The school offers remedial classes for struggling students
Remedial reading programs help children catch up quickly
The doctor prescribed remedial exercises for his injury
Remedial massage therapy reduced her chronic pain significantly

definitions: tending to remind one of something through similarity or association
examples: The smell was reminiscent of her grandmother's kitchen
His style is reminiscent of early jazz musicians
The architecture was reminiscent of colonial period buildings
Her voice was strongly reminiscent of famous singers

definitions: feeling deep regret or guilt for wrongdoing or harm caused to others
examples: The defendant appeared genuinely remorseful during the sentencing
She felt deeply remorseful about her harsh words
His remorseful letter apologized for all the pain caused
The remorseful teenager promised never to steal again

definitions: situated far from the main centers of population or activity
having very little connection with or relationship to something
emotionally distant and not showing feelings or being friendly
examples: They lived in a remote village in the mountains
The remote island had no internet connection available
There's only a remote chance of success here
The connection seems remote to our current discussion
He remained remote and aloof during the meeting
Her remote manner made conversation difficult with others

definitions: able to be taken away or off from the position occupied
examples: The jacket has removable sleeves for different weather
This phone case has a removable battery compartment
The stains proved removable with the right cleaning solution
All removable parts should be washed separately first

definitions: taken away from a place or position previously occupied
separated by a particular number of steps in family relationship
examples: The removed furniture left empty spaces everywhere
All removed items were catalogued for the inventory
My first cousin once removed lives in Canada
She's my second cousin twice removed by marriage

definitions: relating to or affecting the kidneys in anatomy or medicine
examples: The patient suffered from chronic renal failure requiring dialysis
Renal function tests showed abnormal results this time
The renal artery supplies blood to both kidneys
She specializes in renal medicine at the hospital

definitions: having deserted a group or cause to adopt a contrary position
examples: The renegade soldiers formed their own militia group
A renegade scientist challenged the established theories
The renegade artist refused to follow traditional styles
Several renegade members left to start competing company

definitions: able to be renewed or extended for additional periods of time
relating to natural resources that are naturally replenished on human timescales
examples: Your passport is renewable every ten years online
The renewable contract extends for another year automatically
Solar power is a renewable energy source worldwide
The country invested heavily in renewable resources infrastructure

definitions: restored to a fresh or vigorous state after decline or inactivity
resumed or restarted after an interruption or pause in activity
examples: She felt renewed energy after the vacation break
The renewed interest in classical music surprised everyone
Their renewed efforts finally produced the desired results
The renewed negotiations began with more optimistic expectations

definitions: in the process of restoring something to a fresh or vigorous state
examples: The renewing rain revived the drought-stricken garden completely
This renewing cream helps restore skin's natural glow
They're renewing their wedding vows next month together
The renewing process takes about three weeks total

definitions: known and admired by many people for special achievements or qualities
examples: The renowned scientist won multiple Nobel Prize nominations
She studied under a renowned master of classical music
This renowned restaurant attracts visitors from around the world
He became renowned for his groundbreaking medical research

definitions: relating to or available for renting rather than owning permanently
examples: The rental car was ready for pickup downtown
Rental prices have increased significantly this year everywhere
They manage several rental properties in the area
The rental agreement specifies all terms and conditions

definitions: having been organized differently or again in a new structure or system
examples: The reorganised company operates more efficiently than before
Our reorganised filing system saves considerable time daily
The reorganised department has clearer reporting lines now
Their reorganised schedule allows for better work balance

definitions: having been organized differently or again in a new structure or system
examples: The reorganized company operates more efficiently than before
Our reorganized filing system saves considerable time daily
The reorganized department has clearer reporting lines now
Their reorganized schedule allows for better work balance

definitions: able to be done or produced again with consistent results
examples: The experiment produced repeatable results across multiple trials
This repeatable process ensures consistent product quality
Their success proved repeatable in different market conditions
The repeatable pattern made troubleshooting much easier overall

definitions: done or occurring again several times in the same way
examples: Despite repeated warnings, he continued the dangerous behavior
The repeated attempts finally yielded successful results
She made repeated calls to customer service yesterday
Their repeated mistakes cost the company significant money

definitions: causing disgust or distaste through being unpleasant or offensive
able to repel or drive away particular things especially insects or water
examples: His repellent behavior alienated all his former friends
The repellent smell made everyone leave the room
This repellent spray keeps mosquitoes away for hours
The jacket's water repellent coating protects against rain

definitions: causing something to move away or be driven back by force
examples: The repelling force between magnets pushed them apart
The repelling effect of the chemical keeps pests away
His repelling personality made forming friendships very difficult
The repelling nature of the task discouraged volunteers

definitions: feeling or expressing sincere regret and remorse for past wrongdoing
examples: The repentant thief returned all the stolen goods
She wrote a repentant letter to those she hurt
His repentant attitude convinced the judge to reduce sentencing
The repentant student promised to improve his behavior

definitions: containing or characterized by boring or unnecessary repetition of words or ideas
examples: The speaker's repetitious arguments lost the audience's attention
Her repetitious complaints became tiresome to everyone
The repetitious nature of the work caused high turnover
This repetitious exercise helps build muscle memory effectively

definitions: containing or characterized by repetition, especially when unnecessary or tedious
examples: The repetitive motion caused strain on her wrists
Assembly line work can be extremely repetitive daily
His repetitive questions annoyed the interview panel greatly
The repetitive beat of techno music filled the club

definitions: able to be substituted or exchanged with something or someone else
examples: Most employees feared they were easily replaceable workers
The replaceable battery extends the device's useful life
These replaceable parts are available at hardware stores
Nobody wants to feel replaceable in their relationship

definitions: filled or well-supplied with something, especially to excess or satiation
examples: The museum was replete with Renaissance art masterpieces
Her speech was replete with literary references throughout
After the feast, everyone felt replete and satisfied
The report is replete with detailed statistical analysis

definitions: formally made known or announced through official channels or media
said to have happened though not confirmed or verified directly
examples: The reported earnings exceeded analyst expectations this quarter
Several reported incidents occurred over the weekend
The reported theft is still under police investigation
His reported comments caused controversy among members

definitions: deserving censure or condemnation for being morally wrong or unacceptable
examples: His reprehensible conduct toward employees led to termination
The committee found their actions morally reprehensible
Such reprehensible behavior cannot be tolerated here anymore
The reprehensible treatment of refugees sparked international outrage

definitions: able to be depicted, described, or symbolized in some form or medium
examples: Complex emotions aren't always representable in simple words
This data is easily representable in graph form
Not all mathematical concepts are representable visually
These abstract ideas are hardly representable through conventional means

definitions: depicting objects or scenes from reality in a recognizable way in art
examples: His representational paintings captured landscapes with photographic precision
The gallery features both abstract and representational art
Representational sculpture dominated the Renaissance period in Europe
She prefers representational art to abstract expressionism

definitions: typical of a particular group or class showing characteristic qualities
acting or serving as a delegate or agent for another person or group
examples: This sample is representative of our entire product line
The survey included a representative cross-section of voters
She serves as the representative for our district
The union representative negotiated better working conditions

definitions: depicted, portrayed or presented in a particular way or form
acted as an advocate or agent for someone in official matters
examples: Women are poorly represented in senior management positions
The data is clearly represented in the chart
She represented several clients in court this year
Our interests were well represented at the meeting

definitions: kept suppressed in the unconscious mind affecting behavior without awareness
subdued by force preventing expression or development of natural impulses
examples: Her repressed memories surfaced during therapy sessions
His repressed anger manifested in passive-aggressive behavior
The repressed population finally rose against the regime
Their repressed creativity emerged after leaving corporate jobs

definitions: actively subduing or holding back thoughts, feelings, or actions by force
examples: She kept repressing her true feelings about the situation
The repressing force of censorship stifled artistic expression
He was repressing his natural instincts to conform
The government is repressing dissent through harsh laws

definitions: inhibiting or restraining personal freedom, growth, or natural expression severely
examples: The repressive regime banned all forms of protest
She grew up in a repressive household environment
Their repressive policies sparked international condemnation worldwide
The repressive atmosphere stifled all creative thinking completely

definitions: able to be copied, repeated, or reproduced with consistent results
examples: Scientific experiments must yield reproducible results for validation
The reproducible bug helped developers fix the problem
This artwork uses reproducible printing techniques for distribution
Their success proved reproducible across different markets

definitions: relating to or affecting the biological process of producing offspring
examples: The clinic specializes in reproductive health and fertility
Reproductive rights remain a contentious political issue worldwide
Some chemicals affect reproductive organs in animals
The reproductive system undergoes changes during puberty
